entry.et: Middle English wipen, from Old English wīpian; akin to Old High German wīfan to wind around, Latin vibrare to brandish, and probably to Old Norse veipa to be in movement, Sanskrit vepate it trembles

def.dt: :to rub with or as if with something soft for cleaning
:to draw, pass, or move for or as if for rubbing or cleaning wiped his hand across his brow
:to remove by or as if by rubbing wipe the spots off the glass
:to expunge completely wipe from memory the gruesome scenes American Guide Series: Delaware
:to spread by or as if by wiping
:to make a motion of or as if of wiping something
:a transition from one scene or picture to another (as in movies or television) made by a line moving across the screen
:to fall or crash usually as a result of losing control
